answers.answer: Hello,Unfortunately,without clinical examination it is very difficult to make a diagnosis.A few possibilities to your relative’s symptoms are endometriosis(A condition that causes tissue from the lining of the uterus to move through the fallopian tubes and grow on the ovaries, bladder and inside of the pelvis) , pelvic adhesions , interstitial cystitis(A chronic bladder problem that causes the wall of the bladder to become swollen and store) , spasm of the muscles of the pelvic fllor , irritable bowel syndrome(a functional bowel disorder. Irritable bowel syndrome can be a very difficult diagnosis to make. IBS is called a diagnosis of exclusion, which means that a doctor considers many other alternatives first, perhaps performing tests to rule out other problems) and gastrointestinal or genitourinary malignancies.Pls discuss these possibilities with yur relative’s doctor and check whether they have been investigated or not.Hope it helps.Take care and pls do keep me posted on how your relative is doing or if you have any additional queries.

question: My family member has severe, chronic, debilitating, escalating pain in the pelvic region, as well as other medical issues. She has lost 70 lbs over past 3 yrs and has been to over 35 docs in 2 different cities.  She's in her early 50s.  They removed her gall bladder and performed a full hysterectomy.  They've done numerous tests, have ruled out a prolapse, blockage, diabetes, etc.  The only small relief she's had has been with the chiropractor which helped the neuropathy in her feet.  The doctors are stumped.  We're looking outside of the box at this point.  Any suggestions or ideas?
title: Desperate for diagnosis & treatment
